div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,588] ALEXANDRIA, FRIDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINE, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m., a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 19, 1906.

foreign policy, it was inevitable that the young Ruler could not remain for ever the servant uf his Chancellor’s over-mastering will. His own force of character, his restless energy and indomitable self-confidence urged hun on to make head against the menace of a “Bismarck dynasty." The absolutism of the Chancellor found a counterpoise in the restless and alert young Cæsar, whose eagerness to come into personal contact with his ministers, to understand how the administration really worked, drove his greatest subject to resign. One reads with a real pleasure Bismarck s final warning to Hohenlohe : "Keep him off the subject of Alsace-Lorraine," and the Stadt- halter’s melancholy, “Easier said than done. ’ The Wilhelm II. of the Hohenlohe letters is the Wilhelm II. of the Kruger telegiam, of the naval agitation, of a multitude of vigorous speeches, and of some very real achievements, and of the motto, written with his own hand in the Golden Book of Munich, “régis voluntas suprema lex." Another side—dare we call it the “breezy” side—of the Kaiser’s character is happily depicted. He grasps Hohenlohe's hand with a vigour worthy of Giitz von Berlichingen of the iron grip and startles that elderly and respect- able statesman by drinking to him with such sudden emphasis that he all but spills his cham- pagne in raising his glass in reply. He describes the closing scenes of the conflict as “simply lieastly,” he narrates his version of the quarrel in spirited detail to Hohenlohe as they drive together to the shooting box at Sufflenheim, and avows his own ambition in his frank re- cognition of the fact that William the Great, whose place in the history of the Fatherland was known to all the world, might adopt, without a whisper of criticism, a repressive policy of which his grandson—who had as yet done nothing—could not dream. The words which we have underlined are a prophecy of the Welt-Politik to come. We do not see Bismarck at his best. Obviously it was only the memory of his past services that kept the Ministers loyal to a chief who had achieved marvels but was sinking to the level of an unamiable tyrant. One feds instinctively that by 1880 Bismarck’s part was played. In the years of storm and battle he was the great pilot, a Norse. Sea King delighting in the opposition which he beat down with hammer strokes, a lover of strife and tempest, hard-bitten, unscrupulous, and subtle, above all a man of infinite craft and of an amazingly narrow clearness of vision. As in Slukespeare s Julius Cæsar it is the spirit of the Cæsar of the Gallic and Civil Wars that dominates the drama, so in these letters the Bismarck of 1866 and 1870 still lords it over timid subordinates and trembling foes. In the Kaiser we have the new Germany personified : less restrained, less prudent than the old, but more ambitious, more flexible, and, we believe, less narrow. Bismarck must crush the Socialists, Kaiser Wilhelm will dash to pieces the “Vaterlandslose Gesellen’’ who oppose him, but first the legiti- mate grievances of the workmen must be redressed. Russia must lie conciliated ; but is Austria, the ally, to be abandoned for the sake of brokerage ? Even Prince Hoheulohe express- es his doubt whether the policy of aiding Austria against a Russo-French combination is wise, but the Kaiser will stand by his ally, and Algesiras shows that here at least good faith has been rewarded. We have another sketch, too —the Tsar—• serenely optimistic, pushing on to the Far East, “where our destiny lies," before the Japanese can complete their preparations. His Majesty is pleased to express his odiuiration of their cleanliness and civility, magnanimously over- looks the assault of a fanatic upon his sacred person,aiul while laying plans for their absorp tion or overthrow, declares that it will give him real pain to do them any harm. Wo are reminded of the report sent by the Russian Consul at Shanghai to tho efiect that the Japanese Consul at Woo-Sung had persuaded the Chinese authorities to intern the luckless gunboat Manjûr, and annotated by the im- perial hand with the sublime comment, “That Japanese Consul is a very wicked man." Such arc the straits to which cruel ovents reduce even the Ixjst intentioned of monarchs !

div.head: Ungrateful "Patriots
div.p: The unfriendly attitude of the so oalled Egyptian patriots is the blackest ingratitude for even the most bitter enemy of Great Britain will have to admit that the prosperity, wealth, peace, security, and liberty enjoyed by the Egyptianr of to day under British rale is unprecedented in the annals of the Nile country. -Professor Vambéry, in "Independent.” New York.

div.head: Destructive Fire.
div.p: News oomes of a destructive fire at Beni Mazir, which destroyed M. M Ghabrial’s stores. 800 bales of 801 kantars of cotton, valued at LE. 2,600, were lost, with 400 empty bales and ch- q es, shares, etc., worth LE. 3000. The fire nnfortunately spread to the store owned by Muhammad Abdallah and Judah El Gaied, where it destroyed 100 bales, worth about L.E. 600.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 15 and 16th October 21 vessels, of which 10 were northward and 11 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 599,414.91. Of these 13 were British, 4 German, 1 Russian, 1 Italian and 2 French. The total receipts sinoe October 1 are Fr. 4,338 203.99, and daring that time 161 vessels transited the canal, 69 being north- ward, and 92 son!hward boand.

div.head: Natives and Military Cast-offs
div.p: An Army Order has been issued to the effect that the practice of selling uniform clothing to natives is strictly forbidden. No soldier is permitted to dispose of his old clothing except to the authorised contractor. The G 0. C. directs that any soldier who, after the publication of this order, is proved to have sold any article of uniform olothing to a native, shall be tried by District Court Martial.

div.head: DRINK IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: The House of Commons shewed daring its last session that it intended to at last pay some attention to the conduct of affairs in Egypt and the Sudan, and one of the most vital matters about which questions were asked was the import of spirituous liquors into the Sudan. There appears to be a ten- dency to resent any animadversion made on Egyptian matters in the House of Commons, as though the management of this oountry til mid be immune from criticism, bat all well- wishers of the coantry should welcome any intelligent interest that is manifested. There was a series of questions asbei re- cently in the House of Commons on the subject alluded to above, wh:ch were of the utmost importance to the fature welfare of the Sudan. In Lord Cromer a Sudan Report for 1901 he stated tbit he had drawn the attention of Sir Reginald Wingate to the large amoant of spirits imported daring 1900 into the Sadan. it then amounted to LE. 8,400 (250 tons). Last year the imports nnder the head of "Liquors” showed an enormons increase in five years, and were valned at LE 81,000. The matter will be taken np seriously, it is to be hopel, at the Interna- tional Conference, at which fonr'een Powers having colonies or interests in Africa aie re- presented, now meeting at Brassels, to de- liberate upon and devise means of controlling the slie of alcjholio liqaors in Africa, and this n view of the fatal or serions resalts arising from their immoderate use by the native population. The last conference was held in 1899. Questions In Parliament. Theattitide of the Foreign Offueinth’s nist vita! question for the Sadan is not very lluminating and it is sinoerely to be hoped that the House of Commons will keep an eye on the matter. We append the text of three questions, which were asked in the House daring last Jane. On the 12th of that month, Sir H. Cotton (Nottingham) asked the Seoretaryof State for Foreign Affairs "whether he will famish or procure information showing in detail and as far as possible the plaoes of origin and the quantities and values of spirituous liqaors imported into the Sudan via Wady Haifa daring the several years 1900, 1901, 1902, 1903, 1904 and 1905, supplementing the statements made in Lord Cromer’s annual Répons on Egypt and the Sadan to the effeot th it 250 tons (valued at £8,400) were imported in 1900, 241 tons in 1901, 326 tons in 1902, 561 tons (valued at £119,738), in 1904. and a quantity not stated but valued at £84,000 in 1905, and whether he is in a position to explain the increase in the quantity of spirits so imported. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (Sir Edward Grjy), replied : We have no infor- mation on the subject other than that contained in Lord Cromer’s reports, but Lord Cromer will be asked if he can give the farther infor- mation asked fir. Sir H. Cotton : I beg to ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether any, and, if so, what steps have been taken with reference to Lord Cromer’s statements in bis annual reports on the finanoe, administration, and condition of Egypt and the Sudan, to the effeot that in 1900 he had drawn Sir Reginald Win- gate's attention to the large amount of spirits which seemed to have been imported into the Sadan (od. 1012), page 63, and that in 1904 Sir Reginald Wingate’s attention had been drawn to the enormons increase in the quanti- ties of spirits finding their way to Uganda vift the White Nile, and that the sale of liquors in the Sudan should becarefaHy watched, and if necessary controlled, (od. 2409) page 122, Sir Elward Grey From Lord Cromer’s an nual reports it is evident that this matter is receiving h's cartful attention. Inquiry will be made as to the precise answer to the hon. member’s question. The Brussels Act. Dr. Rutherford (Middlesex, Brentford) : I beg to ask the Secretary ol State for Foreign Affairs whether he will state what action has been taken, in accordance with artiole 12 of the Anglo Egyptian Agreement of 1899, in which the contracting parties undertake to pay special attention to the enforcement of the Brussels Act of 189) prohibiting the importation or manufacture of spiritaous liqaors in the region of the nne where, oo account of religious, or from other motives, the ose of distilled liquors does Dot exist, or has not been developed. Sir Edward Grey : The Government of the Sadan have drawn up various regulations for controlling and licensing the import and sale of alcjholio liquors in their territory. These regulations have been modified and added to from time to time, and the matter is one whioh engages the constant attention of the Sudanese Government.

div.head: SUNDAY AT KHARTOUM.
div.p: "Enquirer” writes to tho London "Tribune” : The Sirdar has reoently called attention to the Bnildirg F’und for the English Church at Khartoum, and the occasion seems a favoar- able one for raising the question whether Sunday should not be observed there as the day of rest instead of Friday The latter day is believed to have been chosen out of con- sideration t r the M liamedau people , but is it against the M h imedm faith to work on Friday 1 If no*, it se hh a great pity to de- throne the Christian Sunday and make it an Ordinary working day.

div.head: LORD KITCHENER IN TEARS.
div.p: A KHARTOUM EPISODE.

An interesting work, entitled "With Lord Kitchener against the Mahdi,” will shortly be pablii-hed by a Berlin publishing house. The writer, Major Adolf von Tiedemann, who ac- companied the Sadan expedition as repre- sentative of the Berlin General Staff, gives the following impressions : "Lord Kitohener’s lack of consideration is well known, and for just that reason, although admired and respected, he is unpopular with other offioers. On the day fixed for the celebra- tion in Khartoum, the company had been order- ed to be in readiness by six a.m. We stood hoar after hoar, but no Sirdar arrived. Eight o’olook oame and went, and then the snn began to burn. Appeariig, however, at nine o’clock, Lord Kitchener wenton beard his gunboat with- out a single word of excuse or explanation. "Later we learned from one of his adjutants that it had ooourred to him suddenly that morning that he had not yet visited the wounded in hospital, so there he had gone without bothering himself about anything else. Reason for Unpopularity. "Another reason, perhaps, for his unpopular- ity is that when 'off doty’ he keeps aloof from the familiar interooarse whioh so often exists among English offioers of very different rank. He is body and sonl a soldier, and his military instincts tell h:m that this oannot be right. I had an impression that it pleased him when I maintained that respeot for superiors whioh we knew so well in Germany. Kitohener often called me to him daring the march and con- versed abont military conditions in the Father- land. "I seldom saw Lord Kitohener riding at a gallop daring a battle, but when he did, even over places covered with great stones, he rode like an expert horseman. He irheld to be one of the best horsemen in an army where every officer is more or less a good rider. "Without in the least being guilty of bravado, the Sirdar seemed absolutely insen- sible to personal danger. The entranoe of Omdurman was not mnoh less than a mad piece of bravery. His ooolness had something humoroas in it. For instance, once when the guDS were roaring away, Kitohener stopped to light his cigarette, quite unoouoerned—in fact, carefully noting which way the wind blew. "Ou his way to England, after the oampaign, he said, ‘Now oomes the worst part of the war,’ and truly he had more horror of banquets, hurrahs, and receptions than of the heat, dirt, and stink of the Sadan. "The Sirdar had overcome the enemy and seized the prizs afters years of work and priva- tion. He had crashed Mahdism and avenged Gordon. But as the hero stood on the ruins of Gordon’s house, while the flags flaw and the cannon thundered, he ooold not repress his feelings, and tho tears rolled down his weather - broi zed face. Happy the man to whom such an hoar of life is given !"

div.head: SULTAN’S SON AS POLICE SUPERVISER.
div.p: The Sultan, having no longer the physical strength to oarry on alone the dnty of going through the affairs that are daily submitted to him.has (nays theConstantinople correspond- ent of the "Manchester Guardian”) brought in his son Priuce Bnrhaneddin as his regular assistant. But fearing that the immediate participal tion of this Prince in tho defepatch of pol tioal and official matters whioh are really business of State wi bout the way having been pre- pared, and at a moment when BurhaneddiD is as yet without official title and the coup d'état is still only in the air, would infallibly lead to oomplioations at home as we'l as in Turkey’s foreign relations, Abdul Hamid has thought it best to begin by getting rid ot one part of his harden, and has entrusted his son with the supervision of the secret police and with the task of going throogh the 5,000 reports of spies which, withoot exaggeration, retch b:m on an average every day.

div.head: THE LATEST “AROOTY.”
div.p: MR. BLUNT’S M ATARI EH ESTATE.

Mr. Wilfrid Blunt is not above taking full advantage of the work of Lord Cromer in Egypt when it comes to a matter of pounds, shillings, and pence. Part of his estate at Matarieh has already been parcelled off in building sites and a number of each sold, possibly to speculators who hope to get rid of them to others at a higher price than they paid for them. These lands, whioh are desert pure and simple, were pnrohased a few years ago for a few napoleons the feddan. They are now being offered to the publio generally at the rate of L.E. 801 the feddan. There is nothing atrocioaa in Mr.Blont taking advantage of the boom and disposing, for L.E. 40,000 or L.E. 50,000, of lands whioh possibly oost him as many half piastres, bat there is something very muoh bordering upon a realtmd up-to-date "atrocity” ia the laying oat of these desirable sites for ^Wbtry residences. The main roads on the Blunt property are five metres wide and the by-roads four metres only. Oa the buildiog sites immediately ad- joining the Blunt property the main roads are 16 metres wide and the by-roads either 10 or 12 metres. How those viotimised into buying building sites on the Blunt property are to provide footpaths on each side of even the main roads and leave room fjr a hand-barrow to get in with their goods and ohattels, good- ness only knows. And is it not time that the attention of the Pablio Health Department and the Pablio Works Department should be called to the mattar Î To permit of a few hundred houses baiog run np in a new district with nothing bat alley-ways as means of com- munication appears to be inviting an epidemic at the first favoarable opportunity, and this so that Mr. Blunt or his agents may squeeze the people ot his adopted country ont of the uttermost farthing to be got for his precioas desert lands.

div.head: A RADICAL ON LORD CROMER.
div.p: Mr. Harold Spender, writing on "England, Egypt and Turkey,” in the ourrent "Contem- porary Review,’’ holds that strong or excep- tional measures should be direotel not so much against ,the fellaheen as against the Turkish agitators or Egyptians in the pay of the Turks. Coming from the pen of so strong a Radical as Mr. Spender, his testimony to the wisdom, the eudaring patience, and the justice of Lord Cromer's role is very remarkable. As Mr. Spender well pats it — "We have achieved their [the Egyptian peasantry’ll] happiness , we must work patient ly for their loyalty. We have no reason to be a-hamed of oar reoord. We have respeotçd the Moslem religion, observed the Moslem Friday, tanght the Koran in oar Bohools, and given to Moslems a preference both on the bench and in the Civil Servioe. We mast not be tarrel aside from this straight coarse. We most wean the Egyptians from the Tark, not wrench them. The world has enough cages for black men. A sullen and cowed population would be a heavy price to pay for our con- tinued occupation—a sad ending to a great and glorious page in oar history. It woald a real triuaq h for the Sultan. For what we really have to defend from him is not our power, which he cannot tooch, bat oar British justice, sanity and mercy.”

div.head: THB £ 3,900 ROBBERY.
div.p: The Coptic clerk upon whom fell the duly of registering the letter containing £3,900 from the Anglo-Egyptian Bank is now under arres*. and the inquiry is being continued. It is well to note that in the very great majority of instances the banks are content with registering packages containing sums of money to no matter what value. The reason for this is not far to seek. By registration only £2 can be Teoovered and by insaranoe L.E.400 It is therefore no advantage to the banks to register or insare with the Post Office and they consequently insare to the fall amoant with Rome insaranoe oompany. By the regulations of the Post Office the publio are boand to insare and declare "papers of value, such as paper money, deeds of sale, deeds of loan, interest and dividend warrants, mortgage deads, etc.,” and we would therefore suppose that the Post Offioe cannot be held legally responsible, as their conditions were not fulfilled.

div.head: INTERESTING APPEAL.
div.p: Amoog the oases that will be shortly heard by the Mixed Court of Appeal is a double appeal brought by the Egyptian Government Railways and by the heirs of the late Me. Achille Albrecht against the judgment of the Cairo Mixed Tribunal ordering the former to pay an indemnity of L.E. 10,000 to the latter. The Administration maintains that the accident was doe to the victim’s fault, and demands a complete discharge from the obliga tion s imposed upon it by the Cairo Mixed Court of 1 Bt Instance. On the other hand, the heirs declare the indemnity allotted them in the first instance to be insufficient and demand its inorease. Me. Scbiarabati Bey will represent the Administration and Me. Lebsobn will plead for the heirs.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT. LTD.
div.p: The Directors of the Corporation of Western Egypt, Limited, decided on the 9ih instant to make the final oall of 5/ per share, aod as three months’ notice had to be given such call becomes payable on the 9th January next. This aotion is of apeoial interest to the nnmer ous Egyptian holders of shares in the Corpo- ration, since their shares will appreciate in vaine, seeing that in all respeots they will then rank pari passu with the shares quoted on the London Stock Exchange. In issuing the notice of call the following commanioation is addressed to the share holders by the Seoretary : "In sending you the accompanying Call Notice, I am directed point oat that the Board deoided upon making this Call so as to ensure the uninterrupt- ed continuance of the construction of the Western Oases Railway, in order that the accumulating Oases freight may be handled at an early date. At present platelaying is proceeding between kilometres 67 and 91, to whioh latter point the line is completely graded in readiness for laying. Orders for the delivery of the balance of permanent way material have beon given, together with instruc- tions for the sending forward of large supplies now ready for shipment. Every effort will he made to complete the line as early as possible in the ensuing year.” We understand that the reanltf obtained on the experimental plots on the new lands brought into cultivation around the wells sank by the drilling staff have been so very socoessful that the London Board are desirous of being put in a position to largely supplement the steam drillers at present at work in the Oases and to undertake land development on a very extensive Boale. Consequently as soon as the large supplies of permanent way material can be transported we shall see the rate of progress of the oonatruotion of its line, the Western Oases Railway, greatly accelerate. Samples of the cereals and other orops, inolnding cotton, (“Yanovitz” variety of wh:ch, the produce of land never onltivated before, is of exceptional excellence)grown on the new lands in the Khar- geh Oasis are on view both in theCairo and the London offices of the Corporation. Some of the re8olts have been so exceptional as to exoite much stir looally, the exoellenoe of the crops being very marked. This is of extreme im- portance in view of the ex’ensive character of the grants of land—600,000 feddans - to which the Corporation is entitled. The aluminous and other deposits of earthy minerals are being steadily worked in antici pation of the opening of the line, and alum leaching is proceeding. Daring Aagnst 140 tons of magnesium sulphate, of which a large deposit was reoently located, wa3 removed, the removal daring the first twenty four days of last month amounting to 141 tons. A large consign ment of the best S.iidi dates is being prepared tor the London market and will shortly be shipped, and altogether the indications are r.u naerous that the intelligent oonduot of the business of this Corporation will eventually, and before any long period has elapsed, give a more than satisfactory retarn to the shareholders. Samples have been received in Cairo of the first orops of ootton obtained from the newly reclaimed lands in the Oasis of Khargeb. The lands were watered from the artesian wells that have been sunk sinoe last winter, and no ferti- lizer was nsed. The samples consist of Afifi, Abassi, Yano vitch and Ashmuni, and are very satisfactory, showing a good staple They have been valned at from P.T. 425 per kantar for the Yanovitch to P.T. 340 per kantar for the Ashm ni.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Comme ces joars derniers, le marohé a ouvert déprimé, pour reprendre pen à pen et olôtorer sensiblement au même niveau qu’hier. Ce sont les Estates qui ont eu les honnenrs de la matinée. De 1 15/16 i's s’avancent à 2 3/32 acheteurs. La part de fondateur a touché le prix de 15 3/4, poor finir à 15 3/8. Parmi les autres valeurs ayant donné lien k qoelqaes mouvement, il faut signa’er l’Agrioole qui monte à 9 27/32, la National Bank et la Delta Light qui fléchissent respectivement à 27 1/16 et 12 1/16, la Cassa di Sconto qui gagne 50 oentimes à 234 1/2, la Delta Land qui s’élève de 3 23/32 à 3 13/16 aohetenrs et le Comptoir qui réaotionne de 6 15/16 k 6 7/8 l’aDoienne et de 6 5/8 à 6 19/32 la nouvelle. Les Markets reculent de 27 k 26/9, tandis que les Cotton Mills remontent de 5/9 k k 5/10J 6. La Bière d’Alexandrie gagne 3 francs k 209 la Privilégiée et 5 fr. k 125 la Dividende. De 18.1/16 les Nongovich Hotels réaotionnent k 18, les Splendid Hotels de 4 k 3 15/ >6 et le Crédit Franoo Egyptien de 5 7/16 k 5 13/32. Par oontre, la Banque d’Orient gagne encore 1 fr. k 136 1/2.

Quelques journaux du Caire se sont permis, k notre grande surprise, de critiquer une ré cente décision de notre association des cour tiers en valeurs d'Alexandrie. Noos oroyons que toute association a le droit imprescriptible de reoevoirou do refuser qui bon lai semble, k la seule oondition de se conformer k ses regie ments. C’est une prétention an moins ourieuse de la part de certaines gens de vouloir tonjours fai'e exception k la règle générale.

Mr. M. de C. Findlay, C.M.G., is proceeding home on a well merited holiday on Sanday nex*. He will prebib'y retarn to Cairo early in Jannary. Mr. de Fm llay, who has beon replacing Lord Cromer diring his absence, has had a hard and tiying su nouer, and we wish him the greatest possib'e benefit from his holiday. Sir Reginald Wingate, the Sirdar, paid a visit yesterday morning to Lord Cromer at the Britich Agency. The interview lasted an hour.
Mohamed Moheen Pasha arrived last night from Shibrikit after an inspection of his estates.
Mohamed Moheen Pasha arrived last night from Shibrikit after an inspection of his estates.
Lewa Henry Pasha has arrived at Cairo.

div.head: A USEFUL INVENTION.
div.p: In order to meet the demand for a feed to deal satisfactorily with materials sooh as sugar, corn, rice, small ooal, and similar materials, which do not olog or stiok in serrations or pocket1» of feeds, the Hardy Patent Pick Com- pany, of Sheffield, have introduced a patent antomatio continuous fe d for disintegrators. This consists of a revolving internal drum or barrel, having oonioal pookets round periphery of drum from edge to edge, and arranged in a spiral or worm form. The material is fed into a hopper, whioh is fixed to the top of the feed dram ; the revolving aotion of the dram carries the material, whioh is deposited in the pookets, to the disoharge opening—fitted at the bottom of the drum box,—and thsn discharges it into the mouth ol the grinding maohine iu a steady and oontinaous f jed, thereby considerably in- creasing the oatput of the grinding mill. We strongly recommend intending purchasers of grinding machines to adopt the above feed, the results obtained, both in quality aod oatput of material, being extremely satisfactory.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Yries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, 18 Octobre.

Le taax de l’esoompte libre k Londres reste à 4 7/8 pour oent. Hier, an Stook Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a rétrogradé de 1/8 k 86 3/8 et rUuifiée de 1/4 à 104 1/4. La National Baük a perdu 1/8 à 27 1 4. L’Agricole est dc- menrt-3 inchangée à 9 7,8, de même qne U Daïra à 17 et la Delta Light k 12. A Paris, l’aotion Crédit Foncier Egyptien a avancé encore de 2 francs k 786. La Banque d’Athènes est restée stationnaire à 145.

loi, en dépit des conrs de clôture pen favora- bles re^-ns de Londres, notre marché n’a pas été aussi mauvais qu’on était en droit de B y attendre. L’indéoision, voire une certaine lourdeur, s’est manifestée sur qoe'ques titres, ^alors que d’autres ont été, au contraire, bien pJtenus. L’allure d’ensemble a été, somme tontr, /^Satisfaisante. Le fond du msr:hé demeore bon, seule la surface semble manquer de cohésion et de relief.

Dana le compartiment des Banq es, la National a été ramenée à 27 1/16. L’Agricole a molli 4 9 8,4 13,16 et la Cassa di Soonto à 233- 234 l’action ancienne et 227-228 la nouvelle. La Banque d’Orient, depuis longtemps délais aéa, a éfé l’objet d’un ben mouvement : elle a pa»fé de 132 à 137 pour clôturer k 135 136. Le Comptoir Financier est revenu 4 6 15/16 l'action anoienre et 6 5/8-11/16 la nouvelle.

Le Crédit Fonoier a avancé k 784 et la Béhéra à 40 1/8. L’Union Foncière s, de son côté, atteint 6 1 2 pour finir k 6 14. La Nile Land a été mieux tenue à 16 7/16 12 et l’Enterprise and Development à 12 13/16. Les Improvements ont rétrogradé 4 6 1/16 1/8. La part de fondateur Agricole du Nil a gagné 3,8 à 8 7 8. L’action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a olôtnré à 4 7/16-1/2 et la part de fondateur à 97.

L’action Allotment a progressé k 3 6 8 et la part de fondateur k 138. La Delta L’ght a fait 12 12 1/16. L’aotio i de oapital Eaux do Caire s’est raffermie à 1.4 at les Jouissances 4 265 266. L\ part de ten dateur Bxpress Nile a réaotionné 4 94. La part de fondateur Qbarbieh a avancé 4 2 1 Les Automobiles ODt'fléchi 4 6 7/16. Dans le gronpe dos valeurs hôtelières, les Nangovioh ont olôtnré 4 18 1/16 1/8. Les Egyptian se sont alourdis 4 6 7/8. La part de fondateur National Hotel est revenub 4 75-76. La part de fondateur Excelsior Hotel a été recherchée 4 1 6/8. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été l’ôbjet d’une bonne demande, qni les a portés 4 3 25/32, aoheteurs. Ei excellente tendanoe, les Hooker ont été échangés 4 1 1/8-3/16. La part de fondateur Epates a haussé 4 15 5/8 pour terminer 4 15 1/8, gagnant 3/4 de livre. Les Markets ont faibli à 27 sh. et 1 >s Sait and Soda 4 23 sh. 9 La New Egyptian a été négociée à 33 sh. 9-34 et la Khédivial Mail 4 36 sh.

Si noe informations sont exactes, le domaine deGonrhal, appartenant 4 l’Egyptmn Land and General Trust (Hooker) aurait été définitive- ment venda 4 an groupe de capitalistes du Caire et d’Alexandrie. Le contrat aurait été signé anjonrd’hai vers midi. L’affaire laisserait au Trust un bénéfice d’en- viron 45,000 livres et non de 54,000 ou de 60,000, oomme on l’avait prétendn

Le mouvement de hausse qui s’est dessiné 068 joura-oi sur les Sait and Soda est attriboé, comme il fallait s’y attendre, 4 la réédition du la rumeur saivant laqnel'e les négociation pour la fasion de cette Société avec la Port- Saïd Sait Association auraient été ou bien se raient sur le point d’être reprises.

Nous détaohons d’fme lettre de Londres, en date do 12 Ojtobre, le passage luivant : "La Banq ie d’Angleterre a, cette semaine, élevé son taux d’escompte 4 5 %, et notre msr* ché s’est troavé rassaré par cette mesure qni, d’après l’opinion de beaucoup de banquiers, a été prise nu peu tardivement. Les reports de liquidation de mi octobre ont été faits dans 1er environs de 6 1/2 pour cent, et la tendance générale de notre marché-est pour un raffer missement des coars.

Les petites valears égyptiennes ont donné lieu 4 des affaires assez nombreuses. Les Delta Land ont été recherchés et ont monté de 3 3/8 4 8 3/4. Les Markets et les Sait and Soda ont été également demandés, les premiers, sur- tout ; mais le titre est rare. Les New Egyptian ont donné lieu 4 pas mal de transactions , aujourd’hui plus de 1000 titres ont été acbetén 4 31 sh. 6. "Poor ce qui est de la situation mouétaire, la Banque d’Angleterre n’est plus appelée 4 fournir de l’or aux Américains ; mais ceux r, qui ne sont pas enoore satisfaits, oontinoent a en chercher sur le marohé libre. Le dernier bilan des Banques assooiées de New-York ré vêle une reoradescenoe de la gêne snr cetto plaoe ; la réserve a perdu 8,800,000 dollars et ne dépasse plus le minimum légal qae de 9,415,000 dollars. "Malgré la te ision du loyer de l’argont, les émissions de titres nouveaux, encouragées par les ressources liquides qu’a apportées l’écbéan ce d’Ootebre, commencent 4 reparaître. Une de» plus importantes est pour le compte de la Land Bank of Egypt, qui offre 90,000 oblige tions 4 % de 500 francs au prix de 475 francs ; c’est donc une demands de foods de £1,615,594.”

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM’S WEEKLY REPORT
Liverpool, October 11.

The demand for spot Egyptian bas again been moderate. The lower grades have been more enquired after, the quotations of Fair being raised 3 8d per lb., Good Fair 3/16, and Folly Good Fair 1/8 ; Fine is exceptionally rednoed 1/8 Uppers are unchanged. A fsir bi8iness has been done in futures, and the latest values are, daily : —

American Futures. — The market this week has experienced constant sharp fluctuations, bat the tendency has been strongly npward-», and to-day’s closing values are about 38 (ci 40 points higher than those of last Tharsday. Falling temperatures, and fears of frost have caused highly nervon*», and at times excited markets ; an enormous business has been done. Apparently heavy frosts have occurred in por tiona of ths ootton belt, which preoipitated heavy covering by "Bears,” and large baying by "Bulls.” It b, of course, impossible yet to know the extent of the damage done, and whether the frost has been a really killing one, bat frost at all is serious enough. The present exoitement may be followed any day by a sharp reaction, but if the crop has snffsréd from frost no material reaction will be if long deration, and ahou’d in our opinion be ts-ken -advantage of. Le cautionnement est fixé 4 L E. 100 (Coot) Le cahier des charges est déposé an Burean de la Voirie où il peut être onwlté par 1M intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. 4 midi, les joars fériésexoeptés. Les offres devront être adressées soos pli oaoheté 4 Monsiear l’Admiaistratear de la Municipalité, avant le 11 Décembre 1901. Elles pourroat également être déposées en séance de la Délégation, le même joar 4 5-h. p.m L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la men tion "Soumission pour l’asphaltage des trottoirs de la Ville.” Le cautionnement ou le reça d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément an Service de U Comptabilité Géuérale, avant l’oavertnre des offres et au pins tard le II Déoembre 4 midi.
